cards.question: Create a new git branch
cards.answer: git branch <name> [<start-point>]

cards.question: What are the two types of permissions masks that git stores?
cards.answer:
755 (rwx r-x r-x) (executable)
644 (rw- r-- r--) (non-executable)

cards.question: Set the local "asdf" branch to track the "asdf" branch in the "upstream" remote
cards.answer: git branch -u upstream/asdf asdf

cards.question: What are the four locations git looks in for config?
cards.answer:
/etc/gitconfig
~/.gitconfig
~/.config/git/config
./.git/config

cards.question: Is local config propagated to and from remotes?
cards.answer:
No, only the repo content is propagated. .git/config can
contain sensitive and/or developer-specific information.

cards.question: git: delete develop branch from origin (2 ways)
cards.answer:
git push -d origin develop
git push origin :refs/heads/develop

cards.question: How do you tag a commit with a message-less tag?
cards.answer: git tag <tag_name> <ref>

cards.question: What are the four different forms of git diff?
cards.answer:
git diff [<ref>] [<path>...]
diff between working tree and either index, if index is present
(this is priority), or ref (HEAD default)

git diff --cached [<ref>] [<path>...]
diff between ref (or if not defined, HEAD) and index

git diff <ref> <ref> [<path>...]
diff between two refs

git diff <ref1>...<ref2> [<path>...]
diff between ref2 and the nearest common ancestor of ref1 and ref2

cards.question: What is the purpose of --?
cards.answer:
-- separates the paths from other arguments, such as refs.
Without it, some commands would be ambiguous.

cards.question: List all the commits that changed a file
cards.answer: git log --follow -- <path>

cards.question:
git: how are the ^ and ~ symbols used when referencing commits,
and what do they mean?
cards.answer:
HEAD^ or HEAD^1 -> the first parent of HEAD
HEAD^2 -> the second parent of HEAD
HEAD^^ or HEAD^1^1 -> the first parent of the first parent of HEAD
HEAD~1 -> the first parent of HEAD
HEAD~2 -> the first parent of the first parent of head

The general rule is to use ~ when referring to previous commits.

cards.question: How are tags propagated across repos (fetch/push)?
cards.answer:
git fetch -> only fetches tags that are on ancestors of ref you're fetching
git fetch --tags -> fetches all tags
git fetch --no-tags -> fetches no tags
git fetch refs/tags/*:refs/tags/* -> fetches all tags

git push -> doesn't push any tags
git push --tags -> pushes all tags, but only tags
git push refs/tags/*:refs/tags/* -> pushes all tags

cards.question: What are the two kinds of tags?
cards.answer:
simple: just a name that points to a commit

annotated: a full git object (think: like a commit) that is checksummed,
has name of creator, is dated, has a message,
and is optionally signed

cards.question: What are the paths to heads, tags and remote heads?
cards.answer:
heads: refs/heads/<head>
tags: refs/tags/<tag>
heads at remotes: refs/remotes/<remote>/<head>

cards.question: How do you create a git submodule?
cards.answer:
Go to dir you want submodule in and do:
git submodule add <url>

cards.question: Which file and which directory contain the metadata on submodules?
cards.answer:
.gitmodules: contains the path to the submodule directory, and the url of the submodule remote

.git/modules/<path_to_submodule_dir>: contains all of the things that .git/ would normally contain for the submodule

cards.question: In what two ways is a submodule tracked in the parent's index?
cards.answer:
- in .gitmodules
- as a "directory commit"

cards.question:
How do you get the code from a repository's submodules
when you first clone it?
cards.answer:
git submodule init
git submodule update

or

git submodule update --init

cards.question:
What is the simplest way to ensure that a submodule is in
the state pointed to by the commit recorded in the superproject?
What is the limitation of this?
cards.answer:
git submodule update

This checks out that commit, which leaves HEAD in a detached state.

Any commits made on top of it are likely to be lost.

cards.question: How do I develop the repo in a git submodule?
cards.answer:
1) Check out a branch in the submodule
2) Make your changes and commit them to the branch
3) Push your changes
4) To make the superproject refer to the current checked out commit
   in the submodule, simply add the submodule dir and commit it

cards.question:
What is the difference between git revert, git restore
and git reset?
cards.answer:
git revert: lets you make a commit that reverts the changes made in other commits

git restore: restores files in working tree from either the index or another commit

git reset: allows you to move your current branch tip to a specific commit, potentially deleting commits

cards.question:
What are the three "trees" that are useful to have in your
mind when working with `git reset`?
cards.answer:
HEAD
index
working tree

cards.question:
What are the three useful forms of `git reset`?
Which is default?
cards.answer:
git reset --soft <commit>:
- resets HEAD to commit
- puts changes from nuked commits into index
- keeps working tree as is

git reset --mixed <commit> (default):
- resets HEAD to commit
- puts changes from nuked commits and index into working tree

git reset --hard <commit>:
- resets HEAD to commit
- nukes index and working tree
- commits nuked

cards.question: How do you move a change from the index to the working tree?
cards.answer: git restore --staged <path>

cards.question: What are the three subcommands you need to know to use `git stash`?
cards.answer:
git stash push: put current working tree and index into stash
git stash pop: retrieve working tree and index from stash
git stash list: get a list of stashes

cards.question:
What is the one important thing to remember about the
difference between commands that do things to remotes
and commands that do things locally?
cards.answer:
Commands that do things to remotes must have the remote specified,
and then the branch arguments. Commands that do things locally
have the remote and the branch lumped together in the form <remote>/<branch>.

cards.question:
branchA is based off of main. branchB is based off of branchA.
How do you rebase branchB onto main?
cards.answer: git rebase --onto main branchA branchB

cards.question: How do Github releases work?
cards.answer:
You create a release from a tag somewhere in the code,
then upload any assets and release notes.

cards.question: What is the cleanest way to do global search and replace on a git repo?
cards.answer: git grep -l <term> | xargs sed -i 's/term/replacement/g'

cards.question: What are the three important options of git clean?
cards.answer:
-n: don't remove anything, just show what would be done
-f: required to actually remove anything
-X: remove only files ignored by git

cards.question:
How do you check out a branch that you don't have locally,
but is on a remote?
cards.answer: git checkout --guess <remote_branch>
